dt: {bc}of or relating to the worldly or {d_link|temporal|temporal:1}
{bc}not bound by monastic vows or rules
{bc}of, relating to, or forming {d_link|clergy|clergy} not belonging to a religious order or congregation
{bc}occurring once in an age or a century
{bc}existing or continuing through ages or centuries
{bc}of or relating to a long term of indefinite duration

quotes.t: In the early twentieth century, priests and religious built centers for Catholic study and worship on {qword}secular{/qword} campuses.

Some women, indeed, achieved great renown for their religious scholarship, becoming role models for their peers and silently challenging men, who for so long had held a monopoly in this area. Though they never carried the title of "rabbi" and in many cases eschewed the controversial "f-word" (feminism) altogether, these Orthodox women produced no less a revolution in the late twentieth century than women did in so many other realms, religious and {qword}secular{/qword} alike. By challenging Judaism, they ended up strengthening Judaism.

The reforms of the nineteenth century and the needs of commercial and other contacts with Europe led to the enactment of new laws, modeled on those of Europe—commercial, civil, criminal, and finally constitutional. In the traditional order the only lawyers were the ulema, the doctors of the Holy Law, at once jurists and theologians. The {qword}secular{/qword} lawyer, pleading in courts administering {qword}secular{/qword} law, represented a new and influential element in society.

Bloomberg, by contrast, would be the most pro-immigration, pro-free trade, pro-Wall Street candidate in the race. The third-party candidate he would most resemble is John Anderson, the fiscally responsible, culturally liberal Republican who ran as an Independent in 1980. Anderson won 7% of the vote, mostly among the young, educated and {qword}secular{/qword}. But today those people are partisan Democrats.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}seculer{/it}, from Late Latin {it}saecularis{/it}, from {it}saeculum{/it} the present world, from Latin, generation, age, century, world; akin to Welsh {it}hoedl{/it} lifetime
shortdef: of or relating to the worldly or temporal

dt: {bc}an {d_link|ecclesiastic|ecclesiastic:2} (such as a diocesan priest) not bound by monastic vows or rules {bc}a member of the secular clergy

shortdef: an ecclesiastic (such as a diocesan priest) not bound by monastic vows or rules : a member of the secular clergy

dt: {bc}humanism {dx_def}see {dxt|humanism||3}{/dx_def} viewed especially as relying on reason, logic, and naturalism {dx_def}see {dxt|naturalism||2}{/dx_def} as opposed to religious dogma and supernaturalism {dx_def}see {dxt|supernaturalism||2}{/dx_def}

dt.t: Some items on the spiritual person's shopping list are easily supplied by {wi}secular humanism{/wi}. Easiest of all are two that people often find intuitively the most perplexing: how can there be meaning in life and moral values in a world without gods?
{wi}Secular humanism{/wi} was the seeking of a middle way between dogmatic belief in God and militant atheism.
… as the author states, his {wi}secular humanism{/wi} offers a cosmic outlook on the universe and our place in it …

utxt.t: … as a {wi}secular humanist{/wi} she has a moral and ethical belief system that is very similar to those found in many of the great religions. She just doesn't believe in gods, the supernatural, or an afterlife. She is, instead, guided by reason, science, logic and a desire to find a common ground and love, between all people.
[Tim] Madigan says {wi}secular humanists{/wi} can criticize dogma and statements of faith while retaining working relations and friendships with people of many different religious beliefs.
… ethical quandaries faced by those of us who try to maintain a delicate balance between our {wi}secular humanist{/wi} values and our scholarly duties …

shortdef: humanism viewed especially as relying on reason, logic, and naturalism as opposed to religious dogma and supernaturalism
